{"title":"Section 2, Page 3","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"PROCEEDINGS
OF THE NEW ORLEANS, ALGIERS, ATTAKAPAS AND OPELOUSAS RAILROAD
CONVENTION.
The convention assembled at 6 o'clock, p. m., in
the city of New Orleans, at the Lyceum Hall, on
Wednesday, June the 4th, 1851.
E. H. Martin, of St. Landry, called the convention to order, and nominated Judge Moore, of St.
Martin, President,pro tern. The motion was adopted by acclamation, and Judge Moore, on taking his
seat, briefly expressed his acknowledgments for the
honor conferred upon him.
John Burns, of New Orleans, was appointed Secretary, pro tern.
J. W. Stanton, of New Orleans, next moved that
a committee, composed of one from each parish represented, and one from each municipality of New
Orleans, be appointed to report on the number of
delegates from each parish, and on a desirable basis
for voting. The motion was adopted, and a committee appointed, consisting of—
J. W. STANTON, Chairman, from Second Municipality,
J B. BELLOCQ,
" First
P. G. COLLINS,
" Third
JOHN E. KING,
" St. Landry,
BENJ. P. PAXTON,
" Lafayette,
GEN. ALEX. DbCLOUET,
" St. Martin,
THOMAS 1. FOSTER,
" St. Mary,
R. A. JOURDAN,
